channel.title: Fire Warnings and Advice
channel.description: Victoria, Australia - Fire Warnings and Advice

item.title: Community Update
item.description:
This update is being issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning on behalf of the Wye River Separation Creek Area.

Information:

This is the final Community Update for the Wye River Jamieson Track Bushfire and replaces the current Advice Message for this bushfire. 

The Great Ocean Road is open for business and day visitors and campers are most welcome and encourage to experience what the Surf Coast and Greater Otways have to offer.

During your travel, please watch out for our Fire Crews who are continuing to clear tracks, manage hazardous trees and patrol the bushfire impacted areas, and while this bushfire remains under control you may still see smoke from time to time. 

Also be aware that there are a number of tracks and camp sites that remain closed for public safety in the Otway National Park and to adhere to all traffic management conditions that are imposed on the Great Ocean Road and within the bushfire effected areas.

For ongoing information and advice about bushfires and for Planned Burning please access the following links

Road, tracks and Campsite Closures –  www.vicroads.vic.gov.au\traffic and road use   and www.Parks.vic.gov.au/safety 

Health & Heat Alerts  -  www.dhhs.vic.gov.au

Bushfire Recovery Information –   www.colacotway.vic.gov.au and www.wyesepconnect.info  

Community Planned Burn Information  – www.pbns.vic.gov.au   

DELWP Regional feedback – Managing Operation Risks -  swregion.rbc@delwp.vic.gov.au

CFA Fire Ready information – www.cfa.vic.gov.au

Emergency Management Victoria – www.emv.vic.gov.au

Add detail
For information regarding Bushfires and your health visit www.health.vic.gov.au/environment/bushfires.htm
  • Anyone with concerns about their health should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.
Useful Information:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • Call the Victorian Bushfire Information Line (VBIL) on freecall 1800 240 667.

Counselling & Support Services:

  • Lifeline www.lifeline.org.au phone: 13 11 14
  • Beyond Blue www.beyondblue.org.au     phone 1300 224 636
  • Kids Helpline www.kidshelp.com.au       phone 1800 551 800
  • SANE Australia www.sane.org                  phone 1800 187 263

Stay Informed:
  • Tune to ABC Local radio and commercial radio stations.
  • Deaf, hard of hearing or if you have a speech/communication impairment you can contact VBIL via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English. call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VBIL.  If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.

item.title: Community Update
item.description:
This update is being issued by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning for communities around the Loddon River at Cairn Curran and Laanecoorie Reservoirs.

 
Incident Information

People are still advised to avoid direct contact with water affected by Blue Green Algae (BGA).


Cairn Curran Reservoir

The BGA alert level for Cairn Curran Reservoir remains red.  Warning signs of the  presence of BGA are located at public launching areas at the reservoir.

Visitors to Cairn Curran Reservoir are also advised that due to low water levels, all vessels are now restricted to 5 knots.

The algal bloom at Cairn Curren is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the waterways and/or cooler conditions to slow the algae activity.

Laanecoorie Reservoir

The alert level for Laanecoorie Reservoir remains red due to the presence of widespread and consistent scumming observed by Goulburn Murray Water.  Warning signs of the  presence of BGA are located at public launching areas.

General Information

Ongoing testing is also showing that in some areas, algae levels have been fluctuating.

Because of the ongoing risk, algae warnings and alerts will stay in place until there are at least two "safe level" Blue Green Algae readings five days apart. This will also mean that specific parts of the river may be declared safe section by section, not the whole length of the river at one time.

Water Authorities and the Murray Regional Algal Coordinating Committee continue to monitor the Blue Green Algae situation closely. Regular testing will continue to identify as early as possible, any new outbreaks or changes that may indicate an easing of the situation to a safe level.

Emergency services will advise the community, as soon as is possible, when algae testing shows the sections of the river that are at safe levels and that the community can return to river activities and river water use with confidence. Check this website regularly and listen to you local emergency broadcasters for ongoing updates.

Remember, high levels of Blue Green Algae do not always colour the water blue or green. The water can look yellow, brown, red, blue or green. There may be no visible colour change at all.

 
Health & Wellbeing Information:
  • Blue Green Algae is potentially toxic to humans.  For your safety, avoid direct contact with the affected water.
  • Do not use water directly from the affected areas for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe for these purposes.
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water.  
  • Medical attention should be sought if you experience any symptoms resulting from contact with algae including skin rashes, itchiness, sore eyes, ears or nose, nausea or vomiting.

Pets & Animals:
  • Blue Green Algae can be dangerous to animals. 
  • Do not let your pets and animals swim in or drink the water in affected areas. 
  • Do not allow your pets to eat the organs of fish or ducks from affected areas.

Water Supply Information:
  • Town mains water supplies remain unaffected and are safe for drinking and domestic use.
  • People on non- mains water should contact their water provider for advice and support.
  • An alternative water source should be used, where possible, for spraying and irrigating crops.
  • Further information may be available from www.g-mwater.com.au, www.lmw.vic.gov.au, www.newater.com.au, www.gwmwater.org.au or www.gvwater.vic.gov.au

 
Agricultural Information:
  • Irrigators and livestock managers need to be alert to avoid contaminating produce and exposing livestock to water affected with Blue Green Algae.
  • The drinking of Blue Green Algae contaminated water can cause deaths in livestock. Producers are advised to access alternative stock water supplies if they suspect blue-green algal contamination. Pastures that have been irrigated using affected water should not be grazed for at least seven days.
  • If Blue Green Algae poisoning is suspected in livestock, or a number of livestock die suddenly, contact your local veterinarian or DEDJTR animal health staff. Agriculture Victoria has responded to several reports of sudden death or illnesses in livestock, to date none of these have been confirmed as Blue Green Algae poisoning.
  • Irrigation water contaminated with Blue Green Algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. This is particularly important for fruit and vegetables that are likely to be eaten raw such as apples, grapes, tomatoes, strawberries, cabbages, lettuce and other salad greens.
  • Horticultural produce from the affected areas is safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding Blue Green Algae.

Financial and Other Supports for farmers
  • High levels of financial stress are being reported by farmers in Northern Victoria as a result of dry seasonal conditions. A range of support – including family events, workshops and technical help – is available for farmers right across the state who are dealing with blue-green algae on top of the current seasonal conditions. More information: www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/drought
  • A range of support is available to help farmers deal with financial stress and hardship through existing agriculture extension programs and the Drought Support Package. These include Rural Financial Counselling, Farm Household Grants, Stock Containment Area Grants and Drought Concessional Loans. For more information visitt www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae
  • Information and advice on the impacts of Blue Green Algae on agriculture has been made available on the Agriculture Victoria website www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.
  • Managing farm water supplies is a challenge, given the variable climatic conditions and the blue-green algae outbreak affecting some water supplies. Planning is one approach to managing the risk associated with running out of water. 

Information on planning farm water supplies and how to access Emergency Water Access Points is available at www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.

Boating, Fishing and Hunting Information:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating.  
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected areas.
  • Victorian duck hunting season is open and the advice for fish also applies to ducks.
 
Other Information:
  • Visit www.g-mwater.com.au/bluegreenalgae-alert/ for the most recent Blue Green Algae alerts and public warnings
  • Go to www.agriculture.vic.gov.au for specific information on Agriculture
  • Go to Health Victoria's website for specific public health information : www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria/blue-green-algae-and-health
  • Anyone with concerns about their health should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024.


Stay Informed:
  • Tune to ABC Local radio and commercial radio stations.
  • Visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au.

item.title: Community Update
item.description:
This update is being issued by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning for the Murray River - Robinvale, Red Cliffs, Mildura to Wentworth (NSW) area.

Incident Information:

High levels of Blue Green Algae have been detected in the Murray River from Robinvale, Red Cliffs, Karadoc, Mildura and Wentworth.

The Murray Regional Algal Coordinating Committee today extended the red alert warning for blue-green algae for the Murray River from Swan Hill through to Red Cliffs.

 

A red alert warning is now in place for the Murray River from and including Hume Dam to the Lock 9 weir pool, as well as the Edward, Niemur and Wakool river systems.

 

The extension of the red alert area in this section of the river follows further testing undertaken by local water authorities.


A red alert warning is currently in place for Robinvale, Red Cliffs, Karadoc, Mildura, Wentworth and Lake Cullullerain.  The Algal Bloom in this area is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the waterways and/or cooler conditions to slow the algae activity.  

Ongoing testing is also showing that in some areas, algae levels continue to rise and fall.  The areas mentioned in this advice are currently at the red alert level.

Because of the ongoing risk, algae warnings and alerts will stay in place until there are at least two "safe level" Blue Green Algae readings five days apart. This will also mean that specific parts of the river may be declared safe section by section, not the whole length of the river at one time.

Water Authorities and the Murray Regional Algal Coordinating Committee continue to monitor the Blue Green Algae situation closely. Regular testing will continue to identify as early as possible, any new outbreaks or changes that may indicate an easing of the situation to a safe level.

Emergency services will advise the community, as soon as is possible, when algae testing shows the sections of the river that are at safe levels and that the community can return to river activities and river water use with confidence. Check this website regularly and listen to you local emergency broadcasters for ongoing updates.
 
Remember, high levels of Blue Green Algae do not always colour the water blue or green. The water can look yellow, brown, red, blue or green. There may be no visible colour change at all.

Tourism Information:

There are many experiences on and along the waterways that can still be enjoyed: cruises, golf, bike riding, bushwalking, wonderful food and wine etc.  For tourist information go to:  www.visithemurrray.com.au


Health & Wellbeing Information:

  • Blue Green Algae is potentially toxic to humans.  For your safety, avoid direct contact with the affected water.
  • Do not use water directly from the affected areas for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe for these purposes.
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water.  
  • Medical attention should be sought if you experience any symptoms resulting from contact with algae including skin rashes, itchiness, sore eyes, ears or nose, nausea or vomiting.

Pets & Animals:
  • Blue Green Algae can be dangerous to animals. 
  • Do not let your pets and animals swim in or drink the water in affected areas. 
  • Do not allow your pets to eat the organs of fish or ducks from affected areas.

Water Supply Information:
  • Town mains water supplies remain unaffected and are safe for drinking and domestic use.
  • People on non- mains water should contact their water provider for advice and support.
  • An alternative water source should be used, where possible, for spraying and irrigating crops.
  • Further information may be available from www.g-mwater.com.au, www.lmw.vic.gov.au, www.newater.com.au, www.gwmwater.org.au or www.gvwater.vic.gov.au

Agricultural Information:
  • Irrigators and livestock managers need to be alert to avoid contaminating produce and exposing livestock to water affected with Blue Green Algae.
  • The drinking of Blue Green Algae contaminated water can cause deaths in livestock. Producers are advised to access alternative stock water supplies if they suspect blue-green algal contamination. Pastures that have been irrigated using affected water should not be grazed for at least seven days.
  • If Blue Green Algae poisoning is suspected in livestock, or a number of livestock die suddenly, contact your local veterinarian or DEDJTR animal health staff. Agriculture Victoria has responded to several reports of sudden death or illnesses in livestock, to date none of these have been confirmed as Blue Green Algae poisoning.
  • Irrigation water contaminated with Blue Green Algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. This is particularly important for fruit and vegetables that are likely to be eaten raw such as apples, grapes, tomatoes, strawberries, cabbages, lettuce and other salad greens.
  • Horticultural produce from the affected areas is safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding Blue Green Algae.

Financial and Other Supports for farmers
  • High levels of financial stress are being reported by farmers in Northern Victoria as a result of dry seasonal conditions. A range of support – including family events, workshops and technical help – is available for farmers right across the state who are dealing with blue-green algae on top of the current seasonal conditions. More information: www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/drought
  • A range of support is available to help farmers deal with financial stress and hardship through existing agriculture extension programs and the Drought Support Package. These include Rural Financial Counselling, Farm Household Grants, Stock Containment Area Grants and Drought Concessional Loans. For more information visitt www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae
  • Information and advice on the impacts of Blue Green Algae on agriculture has been made available on the Agriculture Victoria website www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.
  • Managing farm water supplies is a challenge, given the variable climatic conditions and the blue-green algae outbreak affecting some water supplies. Planning is one approach to managing the risk associated with running out of water. 
Information on planning farm water supplies and how to access Emergency Water Access Points is available at www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.

Boating, Fishing and Hunting Information:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating.  
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected areas.
  • Victorian duck hunting season is open and the advice for fish also applies to ducks.
 
Other Information:
  • Visit www.g-mwater.com.au/bluegreenalgae-alert/ for the most recent Blue Green Algae alerts and public warnings
  • Go to www.agriculture.vic.gov.au for specific information on Agriculture
  • Go to Health Victoria's website for specific public health information : www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria/blue-green-algae-and-health
  • Anyone with concerns about their health should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024
 
Stay Informed:
  • Visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/bluegreenalgae
  • Tune to ABC Local radio and commercial radio stations.

item.title: Community Update
item.description:
This update is being issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning for 


Incident Information:

High levels of Blue Green Algae have been detected in the Murray River from lake Hume to Murrabit and the Murray Valley irrigation area.

A Red alert warning is currently in place for Lake Hume , Lake Moodermere, Rutherglen, Wahgunyah, Lake Mulwala, Yarrawonga, Cobram, Echuca, Turrumbarry, Barahm, Murrabit, Murray valley Irrigation area including Torgannah Logoon ann the Broken Nine Mile Creeks.

The Algal Bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the waterways and /or cooler conditions to slow the algal activity.

Ongoing testing is also showing that in some areas, algal levels continue to rise and fall. The areas mentioned in this advice are currently at the Red alert level.

Due to on going risk, algae warnings and alerts will stay in place until there are at least two "Safe Level" Blue Green Algae readings five days apart. this will also mean that specific parts of the river may be declared safe section by section, not the whole river at one time.

Water Authorities and the Murray Regional Algal Coordinating Committee continue to monitor the Blue Green Algae situation closely. Regular testing will continue to identify as early as possible, any new outbreaks or changes that may indicate an easing of the situation to a safe level.

Emergency services will advise the community, as soon as is possible, when algae testing shows the sections of the river that are at safe levels and that the community can return to river activities and river water use with confidence. Check this website regularly and listen to your local emergency broadcasters for ongoing updates.


Remember, high levels of Blue green Algae do not always colour the water blue or green. the water can look yellow, brown, blue or green. there may be no visible colour change at all.


Tourism Information:

There are many experiences on and along the waterways that can still be enjoyed: cruises, golf, bike riding, bushwalking, wonderful food and wine etc.  For tourist information go to:  www.visithemurrray.com.au


Health & Wellbeing Information:

 Blue Green Algae is potentially toxic to humans.  For your safety, avoid direct contact with the affected water.

  • Do not use water directly from the affected areas for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe for these purposes.
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water.  
  • Medical attention should be sought if you experience any symptoms resulting from contact with algae including skin rashes, itchiness, sore eyes, ears or nose, nausea or vomiting.

 

Pets & Animals:

  • Blue Green Algae can be dangerous to animals. 
  • Do not let your pets and animals swim in or drink the water in affected areas. 
  • Do not allow your pets to eat the organs of fish or ducks from affected areas.

 

Water Supply Information:

  • Town mains water supplies remain unaffected and are safe for drinking and domestic use.
  • People on non- mains water should contact their water provider for advice and support.
  • An alternative water source should be used, where possible, for spraying and irrigating crops.
  • Further information may be available from www.g-mwater.com.au, www.lmw.vic.gov.au, www.newater.com.au, www.gwmwater.org.au or www.gvwater.vic.gov.au

 

Agricultural Information:

  • Irrigators and livestock managers need to be alert to avoid contaminating produce and exposing livestock to water affected with Blue Green Algae.
  • The drinking of Blue Green Algae contaminated water can cause deaths in livestock. Producers are advised to access alternative stock water supplies if they suspect blue-green algal contamination. Pastures that have been irrigated using affected water should not be grazed for at least seven days.
  • If Blue Green Algae poisoning is suspected in livestock, or a number of livestock die suddenly, contact your local veterinarian or DEDJTR animal health staff. Agriculture Victoria has responded to several reports of sudden death or illnesses in livestock, to date none of these have been confirmed as Blue Green Algae poisoning.
  • Irrigation water contaminated with Blue Green Algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. This is particularly important for fruit and vegetables that are likely to be eaten raw such as apples, grapes, tomatoes, strawberries, cabbages, lettuce and other salad greens.
  • Horticultural produce from the affected areas is safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding Blue Green Algae.


 Financial and Other Supports for farmers

  • High levels of financial stress are being reported by farmers in Northern Victoria as a result of dry seasonal conditions. A range of support – including family events, workshops and technical help – is available for farmers right across the state who are dealing with blue-green algae on top of the current seasonal conditions. More information: www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/drought
  • A range of support is available to help farmers deal with financial stress and hardship through existing agriculture extension programs and the Drought Support Package. These include Rural Financial Counselling, Farm Household Grants, Stock Containment Area Grants and Drought Concessional Loans. For more information visitt www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae
  • Information and advice on the impacts of Blue Green Algae on agriculture has been made available on the Agriculture Victoria website www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.
  • Managing farm water supplies is a challenge, given the variable climatic conditions and the blue-green algae outbreak affecting some water supplies. Planning is one approach to managing the risk associated with running out of water. 

 

Information on planning farm water supplies and how to access Emergency Water Access Points is available at www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.

 

Boating, Fishing and Hunting Information:

  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating.  
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected areas.
  • Victorian duck hunting season is open and the advice for fish also applies to ducks.

 

Other Information:

  • Visit www.g-mwater.com.au/bluegreenalgae-alert/ for the most recent Blue Green Algae alerts and public warnings
  • Go to www.agriculture.vic.gov.au for specific information on Agriculture
  • Go to Health Victoria's website for specific public health information : www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria/blue-green-algae-and-health
  • Anyone with concerns about their health should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024.

Stay Informed:

  • Visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/bluegreenalgae
  • Tune to ABC Local radio and commercial radio stations.

item.title: Community Update
item.description:
This update is being issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning 


Incident Information:

A red alert warning is now in place for the Murray River from and including Hume Dam to the Lock 9 weir pool, as well as the Edward, Niemur and Wakool river systems.


The following areas between Murrabit and Robinvale remain at red alert level: Murrabit, Kiibdrook, Pental Island, Swan Hill, Boundary Bend, Wemen, Robinvale and Wentworth.


The alert level remains red for the following Torrumbarry Irrigation area: National Channel, Gunbower Creek and associated lagoons, Kow Swamp, No.'s 1, 3, 4 & 5 Channels, The entire No. 7 Channel System, No. 2 Channel in the Dingwall and Wandella districts, The Reedy Lakes, Little Lake Charm, Racecourse Lake, Kangaroo Lake, The Tresco Pumped Irrigation District, Loddon River at Kerang Weir Pool and downstream to the River Murray, Lake Boga (Cyanothamnos/Plaktolygbya bloom) and Little Murray River from Fishpoint Road to Little Murray Weir.


The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the waterways and/or cooler conditions to slow the algae activity.


People are still advised to avoid direct contact with water affected by Blue Green Algae. Ongoing testing is also showing that in some areas, algae levels continue to rise and fall.  The areas mentioned in this advice are currently at the red alert level.


Due to the ongoing risk, algae warnings and alerts will stay in place until there are at least two "safe level" Blue Green Algae readings five days apart. This will also mean that specific parts of the river may be declared safe section by section, not the whole length of the river at one time.

Water Authorities and the Murray Regional Algal Coordinating Committee continue to monitor the Blue Green Algae situation closely. Regular testing will continue to identify as early as possible, any new outbreaks or changes that may indicate an easing of the situation to a safe level.

Emergency services will advise the community, as soon as is possible, when algae testing shows the sections of the river that are at safe levels and that the community can return to river activities and river water use with confidence. Check this website regularly and listen to you local emergency broadcasters for ongoing updates.

Remember, high levels of Blue Green Algae do not always colour the water blue or green. The water can look yellow, brown, red, blue or green. There may be no visible colour change at all.

Tourism Information:

There are many experiences on and along the waterways that can still be enjoyed: cruises, golf, bike riding, bushwalking, wonderful food and wine etc.  For tourist information go to:  www.visithemurrray.com.au

 

Health & Wellbeing Information:

·         Blue Green Algae is potentially toxic to humans.  For your safety, avoid direct contact with the affected water.

·         Do not use water directly from the affected areas for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe for these purposes.

·         If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water.  

·         Medical attention should be sought if you experience any symptoms resulting from contact with algae including skin rashes, itchiness, sore eyes, ears or nose, nausea or vomiting.


Pets & Animals:

·         Blue Green Algae can be dangerous to animals. 

·         Do not let your pets and animals swim in or drink the water in affected areas. 

·         Do not allow your pets to eat the organs of fish or ducks from affected areas.


Water Supply Information:

·         Town mains water supplies remain unaffected and are safe for drinking and domestic use.

·         People on non- mains water should contact their water provider for advice and support.

·         An alternative water source should be used, where possible, for spraying and irrigating crops.

·         Further information may be available from www.g-mwater.com.au, www.lmw.vic.gov.au, www.newater.com.au, www.gwmwater.org.au or www.gvwater.vic.gov.au

 

Agricultural Information:

·         Irrigators and livestock managers need to be alert to avoid contaminating produce and exposing livestock to water affected with Blue Green Algae.

·         The drinking of Blue Green Algae contaminated water can cause deaths in livestock. Producers are advised to access alternative stock water supplies if they suspect blue-green algal contamination. Pastures that have been irrigated using affected water should not be grazed for at least seven days.


·         If Blue Green Algae poisoning is suspected in livestock, or a number of livestock die suddenly, contact your local veterinarian or DEDJTR animal health staff. Agriculture Victoria has responded to several reports of sudden death or illnesses in livestock, to date none of these have been confirmed as Blue Green Algae poisoning.


·         Irrigation water contaminated with Blue Green Algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. This is particularly important for fruit and vegetables that are likely to be eaten raw such as apples, grapes, tomatoes, strawberries, cabbages, lettuce and other salad greens.

·         Horticultural produce from the affected areas is safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding Blue Green Algae.



Financial and Other Supports for farmers

·         High levels of financial stress are being reported by farmers in Northern Victoria as a result of dry seasonal conditions. A range of support – including family events, workshops and technical help – is available for farmers right across the state who are dealing with blue-green algae on top of the current seasonal conditions. More information: www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/drought


·         A range of support is available to help farmers deal with financial stress and hardship through existing agriculture extension programs and the Drought Support Package. These include Rural Financial Counselling, Farm Household Grants, Stock Containment Area Grants and Drought Concessional Loans. For more information visit: www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae


·         Information and advice on the impacts of Blue Green Algae on agriculture has been made available on the Agriculture Victoria website www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.

·         Managing farm water supplies is a challenge, given the variable climatic conditions and the blue-green algae outbreak affecting some water supplies. Planning is one approach to managing the risk associated with running out of water. 


Information on planning farm water supplies and how to access Emergency Water Access Points is available at www.agriculture.vic.gov.au/algae.


Boating, Fishing and Hunting Information:

·         Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.

·         Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating.  

·         Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected areas.

Victorian duck hunting season is open and the advice for fish also applies to ducks.

Other Information:

·         Visit www.g-mwater.com.au/bluegreenalgae-alert/ for the most recent Blue Green Algae alerts and public warnings


·         Go to www.agriculture.vic.gov.au for specific information on Agriculture


·         Go to Health Victoria's website for specific public health information : www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria/blue-green-algae-and-health


·         Anyone with concerns about their health should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024.

  

Stay Informed:

·         Tune to ABC Local radio and commercial radio stations.

·         Visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au

item.title: Advice
item.description:
This is an All Clear message being issued by Metropolitan Fire Brigade for East Melbourne, Fitzroy.
 
The building fire in Victoria PDE EAST MELBOURNE is now safe.
 
MFB will maintain a presence in Lansdowne ST overnight. Traffic in the area may still be affected.
 
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
 
This will be the final message for this incident. 
Safety Instructions:
  • If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to exposure, seek medical advice or call 'Nurse on Call' on 1300 606 024.
